bibl.title: Letter from Gertrude B. Updegraff to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 7, 1931

div1.p: Updegraff enjoyed meeting Emilie Lawrence Reed in Washington, D.C. She describes trips to Detroit, Albany, and home to Trenton, N.J.

div1.head: Letter from Gertrude B. Updegraff to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 7, 1931
div1.opener:
The De Witt Clinton
1686
Opposite The State Capitol
On The Park
State And Eagle Streets
Albany, New York
March 7th 1931-
Dear Mrs Reed-
div1.p:
The weeks have
been passing and still no let-
ter to tell you that I miss you-
Our frequent meeting and
little chats were among the
nice things that I associate with
the Burlington-

I do hope that you and your
daughter have been altogether
well and that the winter has
been an enjoyable one.

It had been our hope that
we would have long enough at
Christmas time for at least a
glimpse of our Burlington friends,
but my husband had to hurry
back to Trenton and our fam
ily claimed what time we
had in Washington. It was
most exasperating to run into
the hotel with some trunk
checks and not have time to
see you.

Of course it has been ex-
ceedingly nice to be in Tren-
ton and so near Harl that we
have been able to see him us-
ually once or twice a week.
The De Witt Clinton
1686
Opposite The State Capitol
On The Park
State And Eagle Streets
Albany, New York
He has been having an interest
ing year and of course we
have enjoyed it with him.

I went to Detroit two weeks
ago with my husband and
really saw the city for the first
time tho I had been thru it be-
fore. It has some huge and
some unusually fine buildings but
what I most enjoyed was
visiting Greenfield Village
where Mr Ford seems to be bringing
back to life the quaint old
place with its facinating build-
ings and rare collection of old
things- The village is by no
means completed but never
theless there is much in it
to charm and surely displays
a wonderful appreciation upon
the part of Mr Ford for the per
iods he is bringing back.

He is not forgetting trees to
complete the landscape and
an old stone fence adds much
to the beauty- The whole project
is a beautiful idea and is
being beautifully accomplished.

A party was given where
the Ford old time orchestra
played for the old time dances-
They were lovely to watch - Square
The De Witt Clinton
1686
Opposite The State Capitol
On The Park
State And Eagle Streets
Albany, New York
dances (called off!) besides
the waltz, polka and schotish-
You will know what they were!
So much prettier than the
modern dances. and the dancers
seem to have such good times.

We went back to Trenton for a
few days and came up here
last Tuesday when we expect
to stay for another week.

If you know Albany, you will
remember that its State St. is
built on a steep hill so that
we must go into “second”
walking either up or down, then
when you cross the street you
must tip to one side or the other.
By the time I am ready to
learn the city I expect to be more
or less athletic!

At this hotel we have a maid
(about sixty, I'd say!) who al-
most made me lose my
self respect yesterday when
she told me of an experience
she had losing her glass eye-
You see she was in church
and she knew she was going
to sneeze and naturally that
of the dire consequences, so
she grabbed for her eye but
alas! too late! It simply broke
into smitherines- I'm being
The De Witt Clinton
1686
Opposite The State Capitol
On The Park
State And Eagle Streets
Albany, New York
haunted by that glass eye!
But -- I'm writing words
I fear-

I would like to be re-
membered to my Burlington friends
and to your daughter specially-
Please don't forget me- It
has been a delight to know
you and I'm hoping that
our paths will cross again-
Can you forget how slow I
have been and write to me?
My friends tell me that
I am a better friend than
I am a correspondant. but
I am always making good
resolves and I'm sure the
trouble is not that I do not
think often of my friends.

This carriers love to you and
a real desire to see you-
div1.closer:
Sincerely Gertrude B. Updegraff Address
Stacy - Trent Hotel
Trenton, N. J.
